question: Find \(\frac{\mathrm dy}{\mathrm dx}\) of\(\quad8x^2 - 6y^2 = 25\quad\)  by implicit differentiation
answer:
$$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Begin by taking the derivative of each side separately:}\\
8x^2 - 6y^2 &= 25 &&\\
2\cdot 8x - 2 \cdot 6y \cdot y^\prime &= 0 \\
16x - 12y \cdot y^\prime &= 0 \\\\

\text{Now that we've taken the derivative of everything, let's solve for } y^\prime\text{:}\\
16x &= 12y \cdot y^\prime &&\text{Add the }12y \cdot y^\prime\text{ to both sides}\\
16x\over{12y} &= y^\prime&&\text{Divide by } 12y \text{ to isolate } y^\prime\\
y^\prime &= {16x\over{12y}}&&\square\text{ Rearrange}

\end{aligned}
$$

question: Find \(\frac{\mathrm dx}{\mathrm dy}\) of\(\quad4 x^2y + 2 y^2x = -7\quad\) by implicit differentiation
answer:
$$

\begin{aligned}
4 x^2y + 2 y^2x &= -7 \\\\
\text{Begin by taking the derivative of each side separately:}\\
4 (x^2y) + 2(y^2x) &= -7 &&\text{Use the constant multiple rule}\\
4 (x^2y^\prime + 2xy) + 2(y^2\cdot 1 + 2y\cdot y^\prime\cdot x) &= 0 &&\text{Use the product rule}\\
2 (x^2y^\prime + 2xy) + (y^2 + 2yy^\prime x) &= 0 &&\text{Simplify}\\\\
\text{Now that we've taken the derivative of each piece, solve for } y^\prime:\\
2x^2y^\prime + 4xy + y^2 + 2yy^\prime x &= 0 &&\text{Distribute}\\
2x^2y^\prime + y^2 + 2yy^\prime x &= -4xy &&\text{Get all the }y^\prime\text{ on one side}\\
2x^2y^\prime + 2yy^\prime x &= -4xy - y^2 \\
y^\prime(2x^2 + 2yx) &= -4xy - y^2 &&\text{Factor out }y^\prime\\
y^\prime(2x^2 + 4yx)\over{(2x^2 + 2yx)} &= {-4xy - y^2\over{(2x^2 + 2yx)}} &&\text{Get }y^\prime\text{ by itself}\\
y^\prime &= {-4xy - y^2\over{2x^2 + 2yx}}\\\\
\text{Simplify:}\\
y^\prime &= {-4xy - y^2\over{2x^2 + 2yx}} = {-y(4x +y)\over{2x(x+y)}} &&\square
\end{aligned}
$$
